moderates harm or exploits beneficial opportunities 
  climate resilience  –  capacity for a socio-ecological system to (i) absorb stresses 
and maintain function in the face of external stresses imposed 
upon it by climate change; and (ii) adapt, reorganize, and 
evolve  into more  desirable  configurations  that  improve the

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) will support selected developing 
member countries (DMCs)1 of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) in (i) elaborating, evaluating, 
and promoting innovative ways to scale up climate change adaptation interventions through 
agroecological landscape restoration;2 and (ii) strengthening the capacity of communities to 
restore and manage their climate-resilient landscapes for food and nutrition security. 
 
2.  The  TA  is  aligned  with  the  priorities  of  ADB’s  Strategy  20303 and  will  support  the 
implementation of ADB’s Climate Change Operational Framework, 2017–2030,4 which identifies 
increased climate resilience of agriculture and natural resources sectors as one of the priorities. 
The TA is also included in the 2020 Management-approved results-based work plan of the 
Sustainable Development and Climate Change Department (SDCC).5 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  Nearly 50% of Asia’s inhabitants still live in rural areas and depend on land and land-
based ecosystem services for their livelihoods. However, agricultural and forest lands that the 
rural poor depend on have been degraded because of unsustainable land management practices 
such as deforestation, biodiversity loss, soil nutrient mining, and cultivation on steep slopes. This 
is causing serious economic, social, and environmental problems, such as increased vulnerability 
to climate change impacts. Land degradation affects the rural population's livelihoods by reducing 
the productivity of land resources and increasing agricultural production costs. Degraded land 
also undermines the resilience of natural systems, which in turn increases their vulnerability to 
climate change. The degraded rural landscapes of DMCs therefore need to be restored to meet 
the challenge of adapting to climate change as well as ensuring food and nutrition security for a 
growing population. 
 
4.  With the increasing realization of close links between land degradation and vulnerability 
to climate change, there are growing calls for greater recognition of the contribution of landscape 
restoration to climate change adaptation. For example, restoring degraded agricultural land 
through  agroforestry  will  support  the  climate-resilient  livelihoods  of  poor  and  vulnerable 
communities by preventing soil erosion and maintaining soil fertility.6 Restoring forests also helps 
reduce the local impacts of climate-related hazards, such as landslides. Some studies suggest 
that forest restoration could reduce the peak flows of small flood events and flood frequency at

small catchments. 7 Furthermore, landscape restoration complements the climate-proofing efforts 
of infrastructure investment. For example, restoring riparian forests in watersheds helps enhance 
the climate resilience of hydropower and reservoir infrastructure by decreasing sedimentation.8 
The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change’s Special Report on Climate Change and Land 
acknowledges  the  role  that  landscape  restoration  can  play  in  climate  change  adaptation, 
mitigation, and sustainable development.9 
 
5.  Although  ADB  has  implemented  projects  that  have  successfully  demonstrated  the 
development and environmental benefits of land restoration,10 more support is needed to help 
DMCs fully capture the opportunities that arise from investing in climate change adaptation 
through landscape restoration. There are also gaps in terms of systematically integrating climate 
change risk management into the design of land restoration activities as well as planning and 
implementing those interventions at the right scale, because of technical, socioeconomic, and 
institutional  barriers  including  limited  practical  experience  and  capacity  to  identify,  design, 
implement and monitor landscape restoration projects. Investment for landscape restoration is 
also constrained by limited capacity to use high-level and digital technologies that could overcome 
historical constraints on planning, implementing, and monitoring at scale. 
 
6.  More support is also needed to help DMCs embrace a land restoration approach that 
optimizes the resilience-building outcomes. For example, efforts to restore species-rich and 
climate-resilient forests by using native tree species that are adapted to the local environment are 
often constrained by, among others, limited financial resources, knowledge and capacity to select, 
propagate and use right native tree species and to exercise silvicultural practices adapted to a 
changing climate. Likewise, opportunities to introduce climate-resilient and biodiverse agricultural 
production systems into degraded lands through agroecological landscape restoration exist but 
are not fully realized because of gaps in stakeholders' knowledge and capacity. 
 
7.  The ADB-financed Climate Resilience and Green Growth in the Upper Marikina River 
Basin Protected Landscape TA project,11 which was implemented from 2012 to 2015, supported 
capacity  development  to  integrate  climate  change  concerns  into  subnational  development 
planning. This TA will build on the lessons learned to help further improve access to the climate 
change  data  needed  to  formulate  effective  adaptation  measures,  particularly  nature-based 
solutions for climate resilience; and will carry out targeted capacity development activities that 
enable stakeholders to design and implement climate actions.

III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
8.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: climate and disaster resilience built.12 The TA 
will  have  the  following  outcome:  DMCs’  capacity  to  scale  up  climate  change  adaptation 
strengthened.13 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
9.  The TA will support selected DMCs in (i) elaborating, evaluating, and promoting innovative 
ways to scale up climate change adaptation interventions through agroecological landscape 
restoration; and (ii) strengthening the capacity of communities to restore and manage their 
climate-resilient landscapes for food and nutrition security through agroecology. The outcome of 
the TA will be achieved by delivering the following outputs. 
 
10.  Output 1: Agroecological landscape restoration interventions promoted. The TA will 
support DMCs in undertaking analytical studies to inform the formulation of adaptation policies 
and the preparation of investments in climate change adaptation through the agroecological 
restoration of degraded forests and agricultural lands. Using participatory approaches, the TA 
team will help prepare at least three landscape level case studies across the DMCs where the TA 
will be implemented. The studies will (i) identify priority landscapes and sites for restoration 
interventions, such as watersheds and lands prone to erosion, floods, and droughts; (ii) assess 
climate risk and map restoration opportunities; and (iii) conduct an economic analysis of the 
planned restoration interventions. Potential restoration options to be assessed include tree 
planting,  assisted  natural  regeneration,  agroforestry,  riparian  buffers,  slope  stabilization  by 
revegetation, climate-smart agriculture, and integration of agroecological principles into farming 
practices. The TA team will (i) review issues and challenges of current land restoration and forest 
management practices in a changing climate; and (ii) identify opportunities to improve the land 
management  practices  to  promote  climate-resilient  and  biodiverse  forests  and  agricultural 
landscapes. Opportunities and barriers to use native tree species for landscape restoration will 
be analyzed. The TA team will also examine the cross-sector links of agroecological land-based 
adaptation interventions, such as the food-nutrition–water–energy security nexus, to develop 
approaches that maximize synergy and address potential trade-offs between relevant sectors. In 
addition, the TA team aims to demonstrate the application of high-level, digital technologies, such 
as remote sensing and drones, and strengthen the DMCs’ capacity to use these technologies. 
Opportunities  to  establish  payment  for  ecosystem  services  and  other  innovative  financial 
mechanisms as well as to promote investment from private sector in sustainable land use and 
restoration will be assessed as a measure to scale up agroecological landscape restoration for 
climate resilience. The team will also assess measures to maximize the synergies between the 
adaptation benefits of landscape restoration and the mitigation benefits of reducing emissions 
from deforestation and forest degradation (REDD+) as well as other forest carbon market 
mechanisms. The TA team will investigate sustainable agroforestry or land restoration business 
models and their enabling environments and will identify private companies that follow such 
models. The TA output will inform the preparation and implementation of DMCs’ national and 
subnational  adaptation  strategies  and  plans,  such  as  Nationally  Determined  Contributions 
(NDCs), and help integrate landscape restoration for climate-resilience into the design of ADB’s

investment projects. Finally, the TA will help provide strategic advice to ADB’s new country

11.  Output  2:  Climate-resilient  agricultural  livelihoods  in  climate-vulnerable 
communities promoted. The TA will help strengthen the capacity of communities to restore and 
manage climate-resilient landscapes for food and nutrition security through agroecology. Using 
participatory approaches, the TA team will carry out at least three community-level studies across 
target DMCs to promote community-based activities that support the poorest and most vulnerable 
people, including women, through the integration of agroecological principles in land restoration 
and  management  practices  for  climate-resilience.  Participatory  approaches  may  include 
stakeholder analysis, participation plans, participatory surveys, and participatory monitoring and 
evaluation. The TA team will review and develop climate-resilience indicators and a matrix that 
should be gender-sensitive and can be used to assess, monitor, and evaluate the effectiveness 
of land restoration and management actions in support of climate-resilient livelihoods. The TA 
team will also Identify and carry out demonstration activities of community-level agroecological 
and gender-sensitive land restoration and management options for climate resilience. It will 
assess the economic costs and benefits, as well as the environmental benefits of the proposed 
interventions, including their contribution to food-nutrition-water-energy security, climate change 
mitigation and biodiversity conservation. Among the options to be analyzed are agroecology, 
community  forest  management,  establishment  of  community  tree  nurseries,  forest  fire 
management, increased value-addition and value-chain development of agroforestry products, 
and enhanced access to agroclimatic information. The TA team will evaluate ways to improve 
crop quality, increase value addition, and strengthen the market links for smallholder farmers so 
as to increase their income and encourage them to adopt agroecological practices. It will consider 
the development and use of certification schemes, and access to forest carbon markets. The TA 
will also deliver targeted training. In addition, the TA team will assess and document the local 
knowledge and practices that help communities cope with the impacts of climate-related hazards 
and climate change, and evaluate ways to improve them with modern technologies and innovative 
nature-based solutions. The capacity of stakeholders, such as extension agencies, research 
institutions, civil society organizations, farmer organizations, and the private sector, may be 
strengthened to support farmers in adopting and implementing climate-resilient land-use practices. 
The TA output will inform the actions of DMC governments to mainstream community-based 
climate change adaptation and resilience building in their NDCs and climate adaptation plans. 
 
12.  Output 3: Knowledge on climate-resilient agroecological landscape restoration 
projects increased. The TA will foster knowledge co-creation and sharing and promote the 
incorporation of agroecological landscape restoration for climate resilience into the design of 
ADB’s investment projects in DMCs. The TA team will (i) study global, regional, and national good 
practices; (ii) document lessons and innovations tested through activities implemented for outputs 
1 and 2;  and (iii) organize national and subnational workshops as well as targeted events to 
enhance the capacity of institutions and communities, including women and other vulnerable 
groups, and to exchange ideas and disseminate knowledge. A knowledge and communication 
strategy will be developed during TA inception. The TA team will publish knowledge products, 
including digital online materials such as case studies, good practice guidance, working paper, 
technical notes, video clips, and blogs. It will also publish a limited number of copies of selected 
reports in English and the local language, as needed. These products will be disseminated 
through local and national workshops, and at high-level regional and international forums, such 
as United Nations conferences related to climate change, land degradation, forest, biodiversity, 
and sustainable development.

5 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
13.  The TA is estimated to cost $2,000,000, which will be financed on a grant basis by the 
Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction and administered by ADB. The key expenditure items are listed 
in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
14.  ADB will administer the TA.14 The Climate Change and Disaster Risk Management 
Division (SDCD) of SDCC will lead the TA administration in coordination with ADB operations 
departments. It will select, supervise, and evaluate consultants; and provide staff to act as 
resource persons in workshops. Consultants will screen all activities to ensure minimal or no 
adverse social or environmental impacts as per the ADB Safeguards Policy Statement (2009). 
Procurement of goods and equipment will follow the ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as amended 
from time to time) and its associated project administration instructions and/or staff instructions. 
Any goods and assets procured will be turned over or disposed after TA completion following ADB 
procedures. Project monitoring will follow the design and monitoring framework in Appendix 1.

$2,000,000 to be financed on a grant basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction for Investing 
in Climate Change Adaptation through Agroecological Landscape Restoration: A Nature-Based 
Solution for Climate Resilience, and hereby reports this action to the Board.
